title: 114_s3160
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing our Secrets Act" or the "SOS Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees" as specific committees in the Senate and House, "Department" as the Department of State, and "infraction" and "violation" as terms used in the Act. The "Securing our Secrets Act" defines key terms such as "infraction" and "violation" according to Executive Order 13526, "Inspector General" as the oversight authority for the Department of State, "intelligence community" as defined in the National Security Act of 1947, and "Secretary" as the head of the Department of State. SEC. 3. USE OF NONGOVERNMENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS. Employees of the Department must use only state.gov email accounts, Department-owned telephonic systems, or other Department-managed electronic communications systems for work-related communication. Certification and reporting requirements apply. The Secretary must certify that all Department employees have access to electronic communication systems within 90 days of the Act's enactment and annually thereafter. If unable to certify, a report must be submitted to congressional committees detailing the number of employees without access. The Department must report on employees lacking electronic communication access, reasons for the lack, steps taken to provide access, and measures for recording and reviewing work-related electronic communications for classified information. The Department must report on employees without electronic communication access, reasons, steps taken to provide access, and measures for reviewing work-related electronic communications for classified information. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for employees if in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. The Secretary of State may waive requirements for employees to use government systems for work-related communications if it is in the foreign policy or national security interest of the United States. All non-governmental system communications by waived employees must be archived according to the Federal Records Act. The Secretary of State can waive requirements for employees to use government systems for work-related communications if it serves the foreign policy or national security interests of the United States. Waivers are valid for up to 180 days and can be reissued. The Secretary can issue multiple waivers if they align with the certification and justification provided. Accountability measures must be taken within 90 days. The Inspector General must develop an oversight plan within 90 days to ensure compliance with the requirements by the Secretary and Department employees. SEC. 4. REPORT ON SECURITY REVIEWS AND VIOLATIONS. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing security violations, including unauthorized transfer of classified information, that occurred in the previous fiscal year. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken by the Department in response. This includes disciplinary actions or criminal referrals against the employee involved. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken by the Department in response, including any disciplinary actions or criminal referrals made. Additionally, any remedial training administered to employees and justifications for not terminating or reviewing employees with multiple security violations in the past 10 years must be included. The report required under subsection (a) may not be made public by the Department. The annual report to Congress must include details of security violations, such as the employee responsible, date, description of the violation, relevant laws violated, and actions taken by the Department in response. The report shall be transmitted in a way that prevents public dissemination of protected information under the Privacy Act of 1974. SEC. 5. CLASSIFIED INFORMATION SPILLAGE. The Secretary appoints officials to receive training in detecting classified information spillage. These officials collect random samples of emails from Department employees with security clearances quarterly. The Inspector General audits the use of randomized sampling to detect classified information spillage and includes findings in semiannual reports to congressional committees. SEC. 6. REMEDIAL TRAINING. The Secretary must certify that all Department personnel with security clearances have completed emergency refresher training on handling classified information within 180 days of this Act. Training includes rules for receiving, handling, and transmitting classified information. The curr_chunk discusses the receipt, handling, and transmission of classified information by electronic means, derivative classification, and the handling of foreign government information. The curr_chunk addresses the review and processing of information requests under the Freedom of Information Act, challenges to classification status, and the protection of classified information that has been disclosed without authorization. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements of Executive Order 13526, including the prohibition of automatic declassification of classified information due to unauthorized disclosure and the mandate for the Secretary to demonstrate personal commitment and allocate necessary resources for program implementation. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements of Executive Order 13526, including committing resources for program implementation, optimizing sharing of classified information, designating a senior official to administer the program, and including classified information management in personnel evaluations. The curr_chunk details the requirements for personnel receiving training on classified information, including penalties for violations and a certification of understanding. The Secretary shall prioritize emergency refresher training for employees with security clearances at different levels: Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information, Top Secret, and Secret. Employees must comply with rules and procedures to access national security information. Employees with Secret clearance and below are required to undergo emergency refresher training. The Secretary has the authority to delay this training for up to 30 days for specific employees or groups if it is deemed necessary for critical foreign policy interests, with notification to congressional committees. Employees with Secret clearance and below may undergo emergency refresher training, which can be delayed for up to 30 days by the Secretary for critical foreign policy interests. The term "applicable rules and procedures" includes Federal statutes, Executive Orders, Foreign Affairs Manual, and Departmental guidance. SEC. 7. ENDURING TRAINING PROGRAM TO PREVENT MISHANDLING OF INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION. The Secretary must establish a training program within 180 days to educate Department employees on preventing the transfer of classified information to unauthorized systems, in compliance with federal security standards. SEC. 8. PLAN FOR REFORMING RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION AND INFORMATION ARCHIVING. The Secretary must submit a plan within 90 days of the enactment of the Act to complete reforms within one year. The plan should include a process for training Department employees in identifying classified information. The plan must include procedures for identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests, including intelligence community-originating information, and ensuring intelligence officials can determine classification status. The plan requires procedures for identifying classified information in documents subject to FOIA requests, including intelligence community-originating information, implementing a training program for archiving emails, and annual administration of a sworn affidavit by Department employees certifying compliance. The plan mandates that employees must archive all documents, including emails, in accordance with specific laws and regulations. The Inspector General will report on the Secretary's implementation of the plan within one year of its enactment. The Secretary has implemented a plan and made progress in archiving and securing Department information.
